Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: PPoSS: Planning: Principles for Edge Sensing and Computing for Personalized, Precision Healthcare at National Scale

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Personalized, precision healthcare (PPH) utilizing edge sensing-computing can collect, analyze and interpret continuous, multi-modality data, both physical and physiologic, producing information, knowledge and insight needed for real-time disease onset and progression monitoring at both the individual and population levels. This planning proposal will (i) identify the challenges and investigate the principles and potential solutions for the edge sensing-computing paradigm; (ii) engage diverse academic, community and government stakeholders to collectively define the functional and performance requirements for PPH; and (iii) create and validate preliminary approaches and devise a concrete, detailed plan for scaling PPH to national levels. It is well aligned with NSF’s mission to “advance the national health, prosperity and welfare.” This project can generate enormous social and economic benefits for communities, healthcare systems, and other stakeholders. If successful, the project will enable the monitoring of epidemics (e.g. disease outbreaks/spread, early detection/preemptive intervention of acute/infectious diseases) and the management of chronic physical and psychological conditions. The PIs will 1) disseminate publications, data and systems in academic, industry and community venues; 2) integrate CISE student education (including female and under-represented minorities) at different levels; 3) mentor high-school students on joint health-technology research; 4) cultivate a technology-literate healthcare workforce; and 5) pilot the technologies for immediate benefits to nearby communities while studying how to scale to other rural, suburban, and city settings.

This project will explore, design, and evaluate potential solutions for enhancing the scalability of edge sensing-computing-based PPH in four dimensions of different types of sensing data, analytic algorithms, diseases, health conditions, and population sizes. The PIs will identify challenges and validate approaches guided by three principles: privacy as a first-class citizen, design for faults and exploitation of scale. The team will: 1) define new abstractions and quantifiable metrics for end-to-end security and privacy guarantees across hardware, software and application stack; 2) investigate systems for multi-temporal resolution processing of heterogeneous healthcare data, incorporating composition of components from possibly untrusted third parties and accommodate noises, disturbances or even adversary-controlled data; 3) explore novel AI/machine-learning algorithms suitable for PPH learning and inference, including AutoML for neural-network architecture search, model compression and federated learning at extreme scale while meeting security, privacy and robustness constraints; and 4) develop heterogeneous hardware accelerators and general design methodologies and tools for neural-hardware architecture co-design, efficient acceleration for time-series, point-cloud and language/sound understanding, and on-device edge training.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has made significant strides in integrating advanced artificial intelligence (AI) into edge devices, focusing on efficiency and accessibility. This endeavor has greatly contributed to the fields of machine learning and AI by developing new techniques for reducing computational demands, enabling sophisticated AI applications to run on low-power devices without compromising performance. These innovations facilitate real-time, on-device data processing, which is crucial for sensitive healthcare applications, ensuring patient privacy and data security where AI algorithms need to run locally.

The intellectual merit of this project lies in its pioneering contributions to the field of efficient AI computing, particularly in making AI models more efficient and environmentally sustainable. By reducing the energy consumption and computational requirements of AI applications, the project supports the broader adoption of AI technologies across various sectors, beyond healthcare. 

  • TinyML: Developed MCUNet, the first model to achieve ImageNet-scale visual understanding on a microcontroller, requiring 3.5x less memory and 5.7x less storage than other models.
  • On-device training: Enabled on-device training of tiny models on microcontrollers with only 256KB memory, paving the way for lifelong learning on edge devices.
  • Large Language Model (LLM) acceleration: Developed SmoothQuant, a post-training quantization method that enables 8-bit and 4-bit quantization for LLMs, achieving 1.56x speedup and halving memory usage.
  • Vision transformer acceleration: Introduced EfficientViT, a lightweight vision transformer with multi-scale linear attention, achieving significantly improved performance and speed on both GPUs and mobile phones.

The broader impacts of this research are profound and multifaceted. Firstly, it democratizes access to AI technology, making powerful AI tools available on everyday devices, which is particularly beneficial for economically disadvantaged communities that may lack access to high-end computing resources. Secondly, this project addresses critical environmental concerns by significantly lowering the energy footprint of running advanced AI applications, aligning with global sustainability goals. Thirdly, the emphasis on on-device processing enhances user privacy by minimizing the need to transmit sensitive data over the internet. It enables:

  • Democratization of AI: Made AI accessible to resource-constrained devices,enabling applications in various domains like healthcare, agriculture, and environmental monitoring.
  • Reduced environmental impact: By reducing the computational resources needed for AI, the project contributes to greener AI development.
  • Improved privacy: On-device AI reduces the need to transmit data to the cloud,enhancing privacy and security.
  • Education and training: Developed a new course "TinyML and Efficient Deep Learning Computing" that has been widely adopted and received positive feedback from students.
  • Diversity and inclusion: Mentored students from underrepresented groups and promoted DEI initiatives in the field of AI.

The project has made concrete and measurable impacts, including:

  • Publications: Published over 20 research papers in top conferences and journals, with over 52,000 citations on Prof. Song Han's Google Scholar: https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=E0iCaa4AAAAJ.
  • Open-source software: Released code for MCUNet, TinyML, and other tools, received over 20,000 stars on Github: https://github.com/mit-han-lab
  • Industry adoption: Techniques integrated by companies like Xilinx, Qualcomm,Intel, NVIDIA, and IBM.
  • Awards and recognition: Project received media coverage and awards, including being featured on the MIT homepage.

Moreover, the project's outcomes have potential implications for the healthcare industry, offering a pathway to personalized and precision healthcare solutions that are accessible at a national scale. By enabling efficient and private processing of health data on edge devices, this research paves the way for innovative healthcare applications that can provide timely insights and interventions, preverving patients' privacy without transmitting the data to the cloud, potentially transforming patient care and health outcomes.

In conclusion, the project represents a significant step forward in making AI more accessible, efficient, and privacy-preserving, with wide-ranging impacts on healthcare, environmental sustainability, and societal equity.
